story.text: (Updates prices, adds fresh quotes) By Carolyn CohnLONDON Jan 3 (Reuters) - The yen hit a record low against the euro on Wednesday as investors flocked to higher-yielding currencies, while the dollar strengthened across the board ahead of minutes of the latest Federal Reserve meeting. The yen also hit two-month lows against the dollar and multi-year lows against sterling and the Australian dollar due to the impact of carry trades, using low-yielding currencies like the yen to fund purchases of higher-yielding assets. The euro has hit successive record highs against the yen in recent weeks, as investors look for a quicker pace of monetary tightening in the euro zone than in Japan. "It's largely a carry trade story," said Antje Praefcke, currency strategist at Commerzbank in Frankfurt. "People are also expecting slightly hawkish comments from the Fed." A holiday in Tokyo kept liquidity thin, analysts added. By 1241 GMT, the euro had hit a record peak of 158.04 EURJPY= according to Reuters data, its fourth record high in a week, with technical analysts looking for the pair to break 160/161 yen in coming weeks. The euro also hit its highest level against the Swiss franc in almost seven years. "The euro zone has stronger inflation so there is not as compelling a case for the BOJ (Bank of Japan) to hike rates as there is for the ECB (European Central Bank)," said Daragh Maher, currency strategist at Calyon. The ECB is expected to raise borrowing costs to 3.75 percent in coming months from the current 3.5. Japanese rates are seen rising at a very gradual pace from 0.25 percent, maintaining the euro's yield advantage. The dollar rose half a percent to its highest level since late October at 119.45 yen JPY=, and also hit nine-month highs against the lower-yielding Canadian dollar CAD=. The dollar also rose against the euro, with the single currency falling a third of a percent on the day to $1.3233 EUR=, more than half a cent below three-week highs set in the previous session. But the high-yielding Australian dollar hit a one-year high against the U.S. dollar AUD=. U.S. DATA Minutes from the U.S. Federal Reserve's latest rate-setting meeting at 1900 GMT were seen casting light on current thinking for the U.S. rate outlook, with analysts widely expecting that the next move in borrowing costs will be a cut. Fed officials have been talking tough on inflation even as the market bet on rate cuts, and dollar bears will be looking for any hint of a softer tone, after the Fed left rates unchanged at 5.25 percent last month. The Institute for Supply Management's December reading on the U.S. manufacturing sector is also due, while Friday brings the non-farm payrolls report for December. A reading below 50 in the ISM index, which dipped below the boom-or-bust level for the first time in three-and-a-half years in November, would reinforce concerns about an economic slowdown. The ISM is forecast to give a reading of 49.9. Other U.S. data due on Wednesday includes the ADP December employment report at 1315 GMT, often seen as a precursor to Friday's payrolls data. The survey is forecast to show 128,000 jobs created in December, from 158,000 in November.
story.title: forex - euro / yen at record peak , dlr up before fed minutes
